title: 114_hr6528
content: The Act is titled the "Litigation Relief for Forest Management Projects Act" and falls under the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for public participation and consultation in land management plans. No additional consultation is required after approval of the plans. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for public participation and consultation in land management plans. No additional consultation is required after approval of the plans. The regulation addresses the listing of species as threatened or endangered, critical habitat designation, and land management plan provisions. It does not affect the Secretary's requirement to consult with other Federal departments regarding projects in specific areas. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for public participation and consultation in land management plans. The definition of the Secretary is clarified, and conforming amendments are made to the Act. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 is amended to replace "Secretary of Agriculture" with "Secretary" in specific sections. SEC. 3. FEDERAL LAND POLICY AND MANAGEMENT ACT OF 1976. Section 202(f) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 is amended to include provisions for public involvement and to specify that no additional consultation is required after the approval of land use plans. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 is amended to include provisions for public involvement and specify that no additional consultation is needed after land use plan approval. This includes listing species as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act and provisions of adopted land use plans. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 is amended to include provisions for public involvement and specify that no additional consultation is needed after land use plan approval, especially concerning species listed as threatened or endangered or in critical habitat areas. This applies to the Endangered Species Act and land use plan development or revision.
